questions.text: What is a theme in literature?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: A universal message or lesson

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Irony occurs when the opposite of what is expected happens.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which type of characterization shows personality through actions?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Indirect characterization

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each type of irony to its definition.

rightItems: Saying the opposite of what you mean
Events turn out opposite of expectations

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the effect of using dialogue in a story?

choices: It reveals character and advances plot
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It reveals character and advances plot

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A static character changes significantly throughout the story.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: A static character stays the same throughout the story; a dynamic character changes.

questions.text: Order the elements of plot structure.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What literary device is 'The wind whispered through the trees'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Personification

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Alliteration is the repetition of consonant sounds at the beginning of words.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each literary term to its example.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the mood of a story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: The feeling the reader gets

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Tone and mood are the same thing.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Tone is the author's attitude; mood is the feeling created for the reader.

questions.text: Which point of view uses 'I' and 'me' to tell the story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: First person

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is foreshadowing?

choices: Hints about what will happen later
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Hints about what will happen later

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each narrative perspective to its description.

rightItems: Narrator uses 'I' and is in the story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A flashback interrupts the chronological sequence to show past events.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the climax of a story?

choices: The turning point or most intense moment
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The turning point or most intense moment

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which type of conflict involves a character struggling against nature?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Character vs. nature

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the stages of character development in a typical hero's journey.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does 'inference' mean when reading literature?

choices: Making conclusions based on evidence and reasoning
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Making conclusions based on evidence and reasoning

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each conflict type to its example.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An antagonist is always a villain.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: An antagonist opposes the protagonist but is not necessarily evil; it could be nature, society, or internal conflict.

questions.text: What is symbolism in literature?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: When objects represent abstract ideas

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which literary device is 'She has a heart of stone'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Metaphor

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of a subplot?

choices: To add complexity and support themes
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To add complexity and support themes

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each story element to its function.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Hyperbole is an extreme exaggeration used for effect.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the difference between a round and a flat character?

choices: Round characters are good; flat characters are evil
Round characters are complex; flat characters are one-dimensional
Round characters appear more often; flat characters appear once
Round characters are protagonists; flat characters are antagonists
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Round characters are complex; flat characters are one-dimensional

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange the steps for analyzing a poem's meaning.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is an archetype in literature?

choices: A rare and unique character type
A universal pattern or character type
The main theme of a story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A universal pattern or character type

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which literary device involves comparing two things using 'like' or 'as'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Simile

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each genre to its primary characteristic.

rightItems: Set in a real time period with fictional elements

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A narrator is always reliable and trustworthy.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Some stories use unreliable narrators who may be biased, mistaken, or deliberately deceptive.

questions.text: What does it mean to cite textual evidence?

choices: To quote or paraphrase specific passages
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To quote or paraphrase specific passages

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the effect of using short, choppy sentences in a story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Creates tension or urgency

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the narrative elements from introduction to conclusion.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which term describes a recurring element that adds meaning to a story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Motif

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An idiom's meaning can be understood from the literal definition of its words.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Idioms have figurative meanings that differ from the literal meanings of their words.

questions.text: What is the function of the exposition in a story?

choices: To introduce characters, setting, and background
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To introduce characters, setting, and background

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: How does an author develop theme throughout a story?

choices: By stating the theme directly at the end
Through characters, events, dialogue, and symbols
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Through characters, events, dialogue, and symbols

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each poetic device to its definition.

rightItems: A group of lines in a poem
Repeated sounds at the end of words
The pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does 'connotation' refer to in literature?

choices: The dictionary definition of a word
The emotional associations of a word
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The emotional associations of a word

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which element most directly creates suspense in a narrative?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Unanswered questions and uncertainty

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Onomatopoeia refers to words that imitate sounds.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of comparing texts from different genres?

choices: To determine which text is longer
To understand how genre affects presentation of themes
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To understand how genre affects presentation of themes

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange the steps for making an inference from text.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a foil character?

choices: A character who fails at everything
A character who contrasts with another to highlight traits
The main villain of a story
A character who appears only once
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A character who contrasts with another to highlight traits

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which literary device is 'buzz,' 'hiss,' or 'crash'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Onomatopoeia

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A summary includes the reader's personal opinions about the text.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: A summary objectively restates key points without personal opinions or interpretations.

questions.text: What does 'author's purpose' refer to?

choices: The reason the author wrote the text
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The reason the author wrote the text

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is internal conflict?

choices: A struggle within a character's mind
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A struggle within a character's mind

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A bildungsroman is a coming-of-age story that follows a character's growth.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which technique does an author use when they hint at future events?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Foreshadowing

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each character archetype to its description.

rightItems: The main character who overcomes obstacles
A wise guide who helps the protagonist
A mischievous character who challenges norms

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the effect of an ambiguous ending in literature?

choices: It frustrates readers and should be avoided
It allows readers to interpret the conclusion themselves
It always leads to a sequel
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It allows readers to interpret the conclusion themselves

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The protagonist is always a morally good character.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: A protagonist is simply the main character; they can be an anti-hero or morally complex.

questions.text: Order the elements of a five-act dramatic structure.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a soliloquy?

choices: A speech where a character reveals inner thoughts alone on stage
A brief aside to another character
A poem recited at the end of a play
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A speech where a character reveals inner thoughts alone on stage

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Assonance is the repetition of vowel sounds within words.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each literary movement to its characteristic.

rightItems: Shows humans controlled by environment and heredity

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does 'denotation' mean?

choices: The literal dictionary definition of a word
The emotional associations of a word
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The literal dictionary definition of a word

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A story can have only one theme.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Complex literary works often explore multiple themes simultaneously.

questions.text: Which term describes the sequence of events in a story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Plot

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of an epilogue?

choices: To provide closure or reveal what happens after the main story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To provide closure or reveal what happens after the main story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each type of poem to its structure.

rightItems: No fixed meter or rhyme scheme

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the steps for analyzing how an author develops point of view.

draggableItems: Consider how the perspective affects the story
Note what information the narrator reveals or withholds
Identify who is telling the story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is an allegory?

choices: A story with characters and events that represent abstract ideas
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A story with characters and events that represent abstract ideas

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Consonance is the repetition of consonant sounds in the middle or end of words.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which literary device is used in 'I've told you a million times'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each narrative technique to its effect.

rightItems: Creates mystery about truth and perspective
Starting in the middle of action

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does 'diction' refer to in literature?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: The author's word choice

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A paradox is a statement that seems contradictory but reveals a truth.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the setting of a story?

choices: The time and place where events occur
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The time and place where events occur

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the steps for determining theme in a literary work.

draggableItems: Look for patterns and recurring ideas
Consider what lesson or message emerges

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a tragic flaw?

choices: A character weakness that leads to their downfall
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A character weakness that leads to their downfall

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each mood word to its category.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An oxymoron combines two contradictory terms.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which example shows dramatic irony?

choices: A character says 'Nice weather!' during a storm
The audience knows the villain is hiding, but the hero doesn't
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The audience knows the villain is hiding, but the hero doesn't

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the function of a prologue?

choices: To provide background information before the main story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To provide background information before the main story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each figurative language type to its example.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is stream of consciousness?

choices: A narrative technique that presents continuous flow of thoughts
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A narrative technique that presents continuous flow of thoughts

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Imagery appeals only to the sense of sight.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Imagery can appeal to all five senses: sight, sound, taste, touch, and smell.

questions.text: Order the elements typically revealed in exposition.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a red herring in literature?

choices: A type of fish mentioned in stories
A misleading clue that distracts from the truth
A character who betrays the protagonist
The main conflict of a mystery
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A misleading clue that distracts from the truth

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A cliffhanger creates suspense by ending at a moment of uncertainty.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which term describes giving human qualities to non-human things?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Personification

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each story type to its typical length.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does 'syntax' refer to in literature?

choices: The arrangement of words in sentences
The emotional tone of a passage
The main idea of a text
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The arrangement of words in sentences

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Satire uses humor to criticize society or human nature.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the stages of a character arc.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the difference between plot and story?

choices: Plot is the sequence of events; story includes all narrative elements
Plot is fictional; story is true
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Plot is the sequence of events; story includes all narrative elements

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each type of characterization to its method.

rightItems: What a character does reveals personality
What a character says reveals personality

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A dynamic character remains unchanged throughout a story.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: A dynamic character undergoes significant change; a static character remains unchanged.

questions.text: What is juxtaposition?

choices: Placing contrasting elements side by side for effect
The main conflict of a story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Placing contrasting elements side by side for effect

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which point of view addresses the reader as 'you'?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Second person

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each term to its definition.

rightItems: The telling of events by a narrator
The speed at which a story unfolds

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of comparing a fictional account with a historical one of the same period?

choices: To prove the fiction is false
To understand how authors use or alter history for effect
To identify which is better written
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To understand how authors use or alter history for effect

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An aside is a comment made directly to the audience that other characters cannot hear.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a leitmotif?

choices: A recurring theme, image, or phrase with symbolic significance
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A recurring theme, image, or phrase with symbolic significance

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Order the process for analyzing author's craft.

draggableItems: Evaluate how choices contribute to meaning

questions.subject: Reading
